questions.question_text:
You have an application server running in a public subnet on a compute instance in US West (us-phoenix-1) region of Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI). The data sitting on this instance needs to be copied to OCI Object storage bucket available in the same region without traversing over the internet. To enable the connectivity between the instance and Object Storage, you created a service gateway with service CIDR of all Object Storage in us-phoenix-1 enabled. You also modified the security rules to allow the desired traffic.
However, when you tried sending the data to the Object Storage bucket, you notice that the data is going over the internet and not via the service gateway.
What could be the possible reason for this behavior?

choices.D: The route table associated with the subnet has no route rule where the destination is object storage service.
choices.B: The service gateway created in the VCN resides in a different availability domain.
choices.C: The security list associated with the subnet has an egress rule that allows all traffic to be forwarded to a destination CIDR 0.0.0.0/0.
choices.A: Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies restrict the access to the object storage bucket.

discussion.content: D is correct but could be better explained. A can't be because IAM has nothing to do with being able to use a Service Gateway. B doesn't matter, service gateways don't reside in a specific AD. C doesn't make sense without the route table properly setup
It is D that is the only obvious choice by eliminating others but I doubt wordings, is the destination meant to be the Service Gateway?

What could be the possible reason for this behavior?
• C. The security list associated with the subnet has an egress rule that allows all traffic to be forwarded to a destination CIDR 0.0.0.0/0.

questions.question_text: Which two choices are true for Oracle Autonomous Database with Shared Exadata Infrastructure? (Choose two.)

choices.D: Billing stops for both CPU and storage usage when autonomous database is stopped.
choices.E: Billing does not stop when autonomous database is terminated.
choices.C: Billing for storage usage continues when autonomous database is stopped.
choices.A: Autonomous database does not support per-second billing.
choices.B: Billing for compute usage stops when autonomous database is stopped.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Database/Tasks/adbmanaging.htm
When an Autonomous Database instance is stopped, the following details apply: 
Tools are no longer able to connect to a stopped instance. Autonomous Database in-flight transactions and queries are stopped. Autonomous Database CPU billing is halted.
When you stop your Autonomous Database, billing stops for CPU usage. 
Billing for storage continues when the database is stopped

B and C are correct
https://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/paas/autonomous-database/adbsa/autonomous-stop.html#GUID-9AF677F3-027A-43FD-B018-9F4A42D5CDE9 
Note: When an Autonomous Database instance is stopped, the following details apply:
Tools are no longer able to connect to a stopped instance.
Autonomous Database in-flight transactions and queries are stopped.
Autonomous Database CPU billing is halted.

A is NOT correct

https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Database/Concepts/adboverview.htm

Autonomous Database onShared Exadata infrastructure uses per-second billing. This means that OCPU and storage usage is billed by the second. OCPU resources have a minimum usage period of 1 minute.

A and B are correct
A. It's hourly billing
B. https://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/paas/autonomous-database/adbsa/autonomous-stop.html#GUID-9AF677F3-027A-43FD-B018-9F4A42D5CDE9 
Note:- Autonomous Database CPU billing is halted.

A and C are correct. when you stop a machine you no longer pay for the OCPU but you pay for EXADATA storage allocated as it still contains data. Also for the answer A, autonomous DB charges the CPU using OCPU/hr so A is true

choices.C: Create on-demand full backups of block volumes, and create custom images from the boot volumes.
choices.B: Create on-demand full backups of boot volumes, and copy data in block volumes to Object Storage using OCI CLI.
choices.A: Create clones of all boot volumes and block volumes one at a time.
choices.D: Group together multiple storage volumes in a volume group and create volume group backups.

questions.question_text:
You are responsible for creating and maintaining an enterprise application that consists of multiple storage volumes across multiple compute instances in Oracle
Cloud Infrastructure (OCI).
The storage volumes include boot volumes and block volumes for your data storage. You need to create backups of these storage volumes in the most time- efficient manner.
How can you meet this requirement?

choices.D: The user has breached either the quota or service limit for using tags.
choices.C: The user is not part of an Identity and Access Management group that gives access to tagging.
choices.B: Some of the predefined values are null.
choices.A: The user is trying to use free-form tags.

discussion.content: Answer is C, as a user should be granted use privilege to access tag

Selected Answer: C
To allow a group to read the tag definitions contained in tag namespaces requires read access:

Allow group GroupA to read tag-namespaces in tenancy

answer C seems correct, but could clarify
acces to « USE tag_namespace »
example from doc:

https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Tagging/Tasks/managingtagsandtagnamespaces.htm
« Allow group GroupA to use tag-namespaces in tenancy where target.tag-namespace.name='Operations' »

I vote for C. while both A & C seem correct as when you try to tag a resource you have to choose between free-form tagging and defined tags, but at the end the 2nd after creating tags should be granting access so i vote for C

I tend to agree with the rest. 
I think it's C.
The following was take from Oracle docs : 

"Required Permissions for Working with Defined Tags
To apply, update, or remove defined tags for a resource, a user must be granted permissions on the resource and permissions to use the tag namespace.
Users must be granted use access on the tag namespace to apply, update, or remove a defined tag for a resource.
Some example policies for tag namespaces:
To allow a group to simply view the tag namespaces in the tenancy (or in a compartment) requires inspect access:
Allow group GroupA to inspect tag-namespaces in tenancy"

Source : https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Tagging/Tasks/usingpredefinedvalues.htm

C seems to be the right answer
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Tagging/Tasks/usingpredefinedvalues.htm

questions.question_text:
As an Oracle Cloud Infrastructure tenancy administrator, you created predefined lists of values and associated them with tag key definitions.
One of the users in your tenancy complains that she cannot see these predefined values.
What is causing this issue?

choices.B: You cannot move a subcompartment to another parent compartment.
choices.D: Sub-compartment D needs to be empty before it can be moved.
choices.C: Both parent and child compartments cannot have the same name.
choices.A: You need to move all the compartments in the hierarchy to the new parent compartment.
